sentence1: He was called the Boy that carries the Ball on his Back, from an idea that he possessed supernatural powers.
sentence2: This boy was in the habit of meditating alone, and asking within himself, whether there were other beings similar to themselves on the earth.

sentence1: This boy was in the habit of meditating alone, and asking within himself, whether there were other beings similar to themselves on the earth.
sentence2: When he grew up to manhood, he inquired of his sister whether she knew of any human beings beside themselves.

sentence1: When he grew up to manhood, he inquired of his sister whether she knew of any human beings beside themselves.
sentence2: She replied that she did;

sentence1: She replied that she did;
sentence2: As soon as he heard this, he said to his sister, "I am now a young man and very much in want of a companion;"

sentence1: As soon as he heard this, he said to his sister, "I am now a young man and very much in want of a companion;"
sentence2: " and he asked his sister to make him several pairs of moccasins.

sentence1: " and he asked his sister to make him several pairs of moccasins.
sentence2: She complied with his request;

sentence1: She complied with his request;
sentence2: and as soon as he received the moccasins, he took up his war-club and set out in quest of the distant village.

sentence1: and as soon as he received the moccasins, he took up his war-club and set out in quest of the distant village.
sentence2: He traveled on till he came to a small wigwam, and on looking into it he discovered a very old woman sitting alone by the fire.

sentence1: He traveled on till he came to a small wigwam, and on looking into it he discovered a very old woman sitting alone by the fire.
sentence2: As soon as she saw the stranger, she invited him in, and thus addressed him: "My poor grandchild, I suppose you are one of those who seek for the distant village, from which no person has ever yet returned.

sentence1: As soon as she saw the stranger, she invited him in, and thus addressed him: "My poor grandchild, I suppose you are one of those who seek for the distant village, from which no person has ever yet returned.
sentence2: Unless your guardian is more powerful than the guardians of those who have gone before you, you will share a similar fate to theirs.

sentence1: Unless your guardian is more powerful than the guardians of those who have gone before you, you will share a similar fate to theirs.
sentence2: Be careful to provide yourself with the invisible bones they use in the medicine-dance, for without these you can not succeed."

sentence1: Be careful to provide yourself with the invisible bones they use in the medicine-dance, for without these you can not succeed."
sentence2: After she had thus spoken, she gave him the following directions for his journey: "When you come near to the village which you seek, you will see in the center a large lodge, in which the chief of the village, who has two daughters, resides.

sentence1: After she had thus spoken, she gave him the following directions for his journey: "When you come near to the village which you seek, you will see in the center a large lodge, in which the chief of the village, who has two daughters, resides.
sentence2: On this tree, about the height of a man from the ground, is hung a small lodge, in which these two false daughters dwell.

sentence1: On this tree, about the height of a man from the ground, is hung a small lodge, in which these two false daughters dwell.
sentence2: Be wise, my grandchild, and abide strictly by my directions."

sentence1: Be wise, my grandchild, and abide strictly by my directions."
sentence2: The old woman then gave to the young man the bones which were to secure his success;

sentence1: The old woman then gave to the young man the bones which were to secure his success;
sentence2: and she informed him with great care how he was to proceed.

sentence1: and she informed him with great care how he was to proceed.
sentence2: and as he was gazing around him, he saw both the tree and the lodge which the old woman had mentioned.

sentence1: and as he was gazing around him, he saw both the tree and the lodge which the old woman had mentioned.
sentence2: He at once bent his steps for the tree, and approaching, he endeavored to reach the suspended lodge.

sentence1: He at once bent his steps for the tree, and approaching, he endeavored to reach the suspended lodge.
sentence2: for as often as he attempted to reach it, the tree began to tremble, and it soon shot up so that the lodge could hardly be perceived.

sentence1: for as often as he attempted to reach it, the tree began to tremble, and it soon shot up so that the lodge could hardly be perceived.
sentence2: He bethought him of his guardian, and invoking his aid, and changing himself into a squirrel, he mounted nimbly up again, in the hope that the lodge would not now escape him.

sentence1: He bethought him of his guardian, and invoking his aid, and changing himself into a squirrel, he mounted nimbly up again, in the hope that the lodge would not now escape him.
sentence2: Panting, and out of breath, he remembered the instructions of the old woman, and drawing from his bosom one of the bones, he thrust it into the trunk of the tree, and rested himself to be ready to start again.

sentence1: Panting, and out of breath, he remembered the instructions of the old woman, and drawing from his bosom one of the bones, he thrust it into the trunk of the tree, and rested himself to be ready to start again.
sentence2: As often as he wearied of climbing, for even a squirrel can not climb forever, he repeated the little ceremony of the bones;

sentence1: As often as he wearied of climbing, for even a squirrel can not climb forever, he repeated the little ceremony of the bones;
sentence2: but whenever he came near the lodge and put forth his hand to touch it, the tree would shoot up as before, and carry the lodge up far beyond his reach.

sentence1: but whenever he came near the lodge and put forth his hand to touch it, the tree would shoot up as before, and carry the lodge up far beyond his reach.
sentence2: At length the bones being all gone, and the lodge well-nigh out of sight, he began to despair, for the earth, too, had long since vanished entirely from his view.

sentence1: At length the bones being all gone, and the lodge well-nigh out of sight, he began to despair, for the earth, too, had long since vanished entirely from his view.
sentence2: Summoning his whole heart, he resolved to try once more.

sentence1: Summoning his whole heart, he resolved to try once more.
sentence2: On and up he went, and, as soon as he put forth his hand to touch it, the tree again shook, and away went the lodge.

sentence1: On and up he went, and, as soon as he put forth his hand to touch it, the tree again shook, and away went the lodge.
sentence2: One more endeavor, brave Onwee, and in he goes;

sentence1: One more endeavor, brave Onwee, and in he goes;
sentence2: Onwee entered the lodge with a fearless step, and he beheld the two wicked sisters sitting opposite each other.

sentence1: Onwee entered the lodge with a fearless step, and he beheld the two wicked sisters sitting opposite each other.
sentence2: He asked their names.

sentence1: He asked their names.
sentence2: The one on his left hand called herself Azhabee, and the one on the right, Negahnabee.

sentence1: The one on his left hand called herself Azhabee, and the one on the right, Negahnabee.
sentence2: After talking with them a little while, he discovered that whenever he addressed the one on his left hand, the tree would tremble as before and settle down to its former place;

sentence1: After talking with them a little while, he discovered that whenever he addressed the one on his left hand, the tree would tremble as before and settle down to its former place;
sentence2: but when he addressed the one on his right hand, it would again shoot upward.

sentence1: but when he addressed the one on his right hand, it would again shoot upward.
sentence2: When he thus perceived that by addressing the one on his left hand that the tree would descend, he continued to do so until it had again settled down to its place near the earth.

sentence1: When he thus perceived that by addressing the one on his left hand that the tree would descend, he continued to do so until it had again settled down to its place near the earth.
sentence2: Then seizing his war-club, he said to the sisters: "You who have caused the death of so many of my brethren I will now put an end to, and thus have revenge for those you have destroyed."

sentence1: Then seizing his war-club, he said to the sisters: "You who have caused the death of so many of my brethren I will now put an end to, and thus have revenge for those you have destroyed."
sentence2: As he spoke this he raised the club, and with one blow laid the two wicked women dead at his feet.

sentence1: As he spoke this he raised the club, and with one blow laid the two wicked women dead at his feet.
sentence2: Onwee then descended, and learning that these sisters had a brother living with their father, who had shared all together in the spoils of all such as the wicked sisters had betrayed, and who would now pursue him for having put an end to their wicked profits, Onwee set off at random, not knowing whither he went.

sentence1: Onwee then descended, and learning that these sisters had a brother living with their father, who had shared all together in the spoils of all such as the wicked sisters had betrayed, and who would now pursue him for having put an end to their wicked profits, Onwee set off at random, not knowing whither he went.
sentence2: The father coming in the evening to visit the lodge of his daughters, discovered what had happened.

sentence1: The father coming in the evening to visit the lodge of his daughters, discovered what had happened.
sentence2: He immediately sent word to his son that his sisters had been slain, and that there were no more spoils to be had, which greatly inflamed the young man's temper, especially the woeful announcement at the close.

sentence1: He immediately sent word to his son that his sisters had been slain, and that there were no more spoils to be had, which greatly inflamed the young man's temper, especially the woeful announcement at the close.
sentence2: "The person who has done this," said the brother, as soon as he had reached the spot, chafing and half beside himself at the gloomy prospect of having no more travelers to strip, "must be that boy who carries the ball on his back.

sentence1: "The person who has done this," said the brother, as soon as he had reached the spot, chafing and half beside himself at the gloomy prospect of having no more travelers to strip, "must be that boy who carries the ball on his back.
sentence2: I know his mode of going about his business, and since he would not allow himself to be killed by my sisters, he shall have the honor of dying by my hand.

sentence1: I know his mode of going about his business, and since he would not allow himself to be killed by my sisters, he shall have the honor of dying by my hand.
sentence2: I will pursue him and have revenge."

sentence1: I will pursue him and have revenge."
sentence2: "It is well, my son," replied the father;

sentence1: "It is well, my son," replied the father;
sentence2: "the spirit of your life grant you success.

sentence1: "the spirit of your life grant you success.
sentence2: I counsel you to be wary in the pursuit.

sentence1: I counsel you to be wary in the pursuit.
sentence2: It is a strong spirit who has put him on to do this injury to us, and he will try to deceive you in every way.

sentence1: It is a strong spirit who has put him on to do this injury to us, and he will try to deceive you in every way.
sentence2: Above all, avoid tasting food till you succeed;

sentence1: Above all, avoid tasting food till you succeed;
sentence2: for if you break your fast before you see his blood, your power will be destroyed."

sentence1: for if you break your fast before you see his blood, your power will be destroyed."
sentence2: The son took this fatherly advice all in good part, except that portion which enjoined upon him to abstain from staying his stomach;

sentence1: The son took this fatherly advice all in good part, except that portion which enjoined upon him to abstain from staying his stomach;
sentence2: but over that he made a number of wry faces, for the brother of the two wicked sisters had, among numerous noble gifts, a very noble appetite.

sentence1: but over that he made a number of wry faces, for the brother of the two wicked sisters had, among numerous noble gifts, a very noble appetite.
sentence2: Nevertheless, he took up his weapons and departed in pursuit of Onwee Bahmondang, at the top of his speed.

sentence1: Nevertheless, he took up his weapons and departed in pursuit of Onwee Bahmondang, at the top of his speed.
sentence2: Onwee finding that he was closely followed, climbed up into one of the tallest trees, and shot forth the magic arrows with which he had provided himself.

sentence1: Onwee finding that he was closely followed, climbed up into one of the tallest trees, and shot forth the magic arrows with which he had provided himself.
sentence2: Seeing that his pursuer was not turned back by his arrows, Onwee renewed his flight;

sentence1: Seeing that his pursuer was not turned back by his arrows, Onwee renewed his flight;
sentence2: and when he found himself hard pressed, and his enemy close behind him, he transformed himself into the skeleton of a moose that had been killed, whose flesh had come off from his bones.

sentence1: and when he found himself hard pressed, and his enemy close behind him, he transformed himself into the skeleton of a moose that had been killed, whose flesh had come off from his bones.
sentence2: He then remembered the moccasins which his sister had given him, and which were enchanted.

sentence1: He then remembered the moccasins which his sister had given him, and which were enchanted.
sentence2: Taking a pair of them, he placed them near the skeleton.

sentence1: Taking a pair of them, he placed them near the skeleton.
sentence2: "Go," said he to them, "to the end of the earth."

sentence1: "Go," said he to them, "to the end of the earth."
sentence2: The moccasins then left him, and their tracks remained.

sentence1: The moccasins then left him, and their tracks remained.
sentence2: The angry brother at length came to the skeleton of the moose, when he perceived that the track he had been long pursuing did not stop there, so he continued to follow it up till he arrived at the end of the earth, where, for all his trouble, he found only a pair of moccasins.

sentence1: The angry brother at length came to the skeleton of the moose, when he perceived that the track he had been long pursuing did not stop there, so he continued to follow it up till he arrived at the end of the earth, where, for all his trouble, he found only a pair of moccasins.
sentence2: Vexed that he had been outwitted by following a pair of moccasins instead of their owner, who was the object of his pursuit, he bitterly complained, resolving not to give up his revenge, and to be more wary in scrutinizing signs.

sentence1: Vexed that he had been outwitted by following a pair of moccasins instead of their owner, who was the object of his pursuit, he bitterly complained, resolving not to give up his revenge, and to be more wary in scrutinizing signs.
sentence2: He then called to mind the skeleton he had met with on his way, and concluded that it must be the object of his search.

sentence1: He then called to mind the skeleton he had met with on his way, and concluded that it must be the object of his search.
sentence2: He retraced his steps toward the skeleton, but to his surprise it had disappeared, and the tracks of the wearer of the ball were in another direction.

sentence1: He retraced his steps toward the skeleton, but to his surprise it had disappeared, and the tracks of the wearer of the ball were in another direction.
sentence2: He now became faint with hunger, and lost heart;

sentence1: He now became faint with hunger, and lost heart;
sentence2: but when he remembered the blood of his sisters, and that he should not be allowed to enjoy a meal, nor so much as a mouthful, until he had put an end to Onwee Bahmondang, he plucked up his spirits and determined again to pursue.

sentence1: but when he remembered the blood of his sisters, and that he should not be allowed to enjoy a meal, nor so much as a mouthful, until he had put an end to Onwee Bahmondang, he plucked up his spirits and determined again to pursue.
sentence2: Onwee, finding that he was closely followed, and that the hungry brother was approaching very fast, changed himself into a very old man, with two daughters, and living in a large lodge in the center of a beautiful garden, which was filled with every thing that could delight the eye, or was pleasant to the taste.

sentence1: Onwee, finding that he was closely followed, and that the hungry brother was approaching very fast, changed himself into a very old man, with two daughters, and living in a large lodge in the center of a beautiful garden, which was filled with every thing that could delight the eye, or was pleasant to the taste.
sentence2: He made himself appear so very old as to be unable to leave his lodge, and to require his daughters to bring him food and wait on him, as though he had been a mere child.

sentence1: He made himself appear so very old as to be unable to leave his lodge, and to require his daughters to bring him food and wait on him, as though he had been a mere child.

sentence2: I will forget the blood of my sisters, for I am starving.

sentence1: I will forget the blood of my sisters, for I am starving.
sentence2: But again he thought of the blood of his sisters, and what a fine appetite he would have if he should ever be allowed to eat any thing again, and once more he resolved to pursue, and to be content with nothing short of the amplest revenge.

sentence1: But again he thought of the blood of his sisters, and what a fine appetite he would have if he should ever be allowed to eat any thing again, and once more he resolved to pursue, and to be content with nothing short of the amplest revenge.

sentence1: He advanced toward the lodge.
sentence2: As soon as the fairy daughters perceived him they ran and told their father that a stranger approached.

sentence1: As soon as the fairy daughters perceived him they ran and told their father that a stranger approached.
sentence2: Their father replied, "Invite him in, my children, invite him in."

sentence1: Their father replied, "Invite him in, my children, invite him in."

sentence1: They did so promptly, and, by the command of their father, they boiled some corn, and prepared several other palatable dishes.
sentence2: The savor was most delicious to the nostrils of the hungry brother, who had not the least suspicion of the sport that was going on at his expense.

sentence2: He was faint and weary with travel, and he felt that he could endure fasting no longer;

sentence2: for his appetite was terribly inflamed by the sight of the choice food that was steaming before him.

sentence1: for his appetite was terribly inflamed by the sight of the choice food that was steaming before him.
sentence2: He fell to and partook heartily of the meal;

sentence1: He fell to and partook heartily of the meal;
sentence2: and, by so doing, he was overcome, and lost his right of revenge.

sentence1: and, by so doing, he was overcome, and lost his right of revenge.

sentence2: He ate so keenly, and came and went to the choice dishes so often, that drowsiness at length overpowered him, and he soon fell into a profound sleep.

sentence1: He ate so keenly, and came and went to the choice dishes so often, that drowsiness at length overpowered him, and he soon fell into a profound sleep.
sentence2: Onwee Bahmondang watched his opportunity, and as soon as he saw that the false brother's sleep was sound, he resumed his youthful form, and sent off the two fairy daughters and the old garden;

sentence1: At the door of a beautiful lodge stood his sister, smiling, and ready to invite him in.

sentence2: Now it happened that there lived in this same village an envious and boastful fellow, who had been once a chief, but coming home always badly whipped, he was put out of office, and now spent his time about the place mainly, in proclaiming certain great things which he had in his eye, and which he meant to do-one of these days.

sentence2: But not one of all them seemed to pay the slightest attention to his request;

sentence1: But not one of all them seemed to pay the slightest attention to his request;
sentence2: for there he hung, the same heavy-limbed, big-headed, be-clubbed, and be-blanketed Ko-ko as ever.

sentence1: for there he hung, the same heavy-limbed, big-headed, be-clubbed, and be-blanketed Ko-ko as ever.
sentence2: He then desired that they would turn him into an opossum;

sentence1: He then desired that they would turn him into an opossum;
sentence2: After this he petitioned to be a wolf, a gophir, a dog, or a bear-if they would be so obliging.

sentence1: After this he petitioned to be a wolf, a gophir, a dog, or a bear-if they would be so obliging.
sentence2: Ko-ko, in spite of all his begging and supplication and beseeching, was obliged to be still Ko-ko.

sentence1: Ko-ko, in spite of all his begging and supplication and beseeching, was obliged to be still Ko-ko.
sentence2: "The bones, however," he said, to himself, "are good.

sentence1: "The bones, however," he said, to himself, "are good.
sentence2: I shall get a nice rest, at any rate, if I am forced to climb as I am."

sentence1: I shall get a nice rest, at any rate, if I am forced to climb as I am."
sentence2: With this he drew out one of the bones from his bosom, and shouting aloud, "Ho!

sentence1: With this he drew out one of the bones from his bosom, and shouting aloud, "Ho!
sentence2: he thrust it into the trunk of the tree, and would have indulged himself in a rest;

sentence1: he thrust it into the trunk of the tree, and would have indulged himself in a rest;
sentence2: but being no more than a common fish-bone, without the slightest savor of magic in it, it snapped with Ko-ko, who came tumbling down, with the door of the lodge which he had shaken loose, rattling after him.

sentence1: but being no more than a common fish-bone, without the slightest savor of magic in it, it snapped with Ko-ko, who came tumbling down, with the door of the lodge which he had shaken loose, rattling after him.
sentence2: cried the wicked father, making his appearance at the opening and looking down.

sentence1: cried the wicked father, making his appearance at the opening and looking down.
sentence2: cried Ko-koor, thinking to frighten the wicked father.

sentence1: cried Ko-koor, thinking to frighten the wicked father.
sentence2: I will be there presently," called the old man.

sentence1: I will be there presently," called the old man.
sentence2: Ko-ko, observing that the old man was in earnest, scrambled up from the ground, and set off promptly at his highest rate of speed.

sentence1: Ko-ko, observing that the old man was in earnest, scrambled up from the ground, and set off promptly at his highest rate of speed.
sentence2: When he looked back and saw that the wicked father was gaining upon him, Ko-koor mounted a tree, as had Onwee Bahmondang before, and fired off a number of arrows, but as they were no more than common arrows, he got nothing by it, but was obliged to descend, and run again for life.

sentence1: When he looked back and saw that the wicked father was gaining upon him, Ko-koor mounted a tree, as had Onwee Bahmondang before, and fired off a number of arrows, but as they were no more than common arrows, he got nothing by it, but was obliged to descend, and run again for life.
sentence2: As he hurried on he encountered the skeleton of a moose, into which he would have transformed himself, but not having the slightest confidence in any one of all the guardians who should have helped him, he passed on.

sentence1: As he hurried on he encountered the skeleton of a moose, into which he would have transformed himself, but not having the slightest confidence in any one of all the guardians who should have helped him, he passed on.
sentence2: The wicked father was hot in pursuit, and Ko-koor was suffering terribly for lack of wind, when luckily he remembered the enchanted moccasins.

sentence1: The wicked father was hot in pursuit, and Ko-koor was suffering terribly for lack of wind, when luckily he remembered the enchanted moccasins.
sentence2: He could not send them to the end of the earth, as had Onwee Bahmondang.

sentence1: He could not send them to the end of the earth, as had Onwee Bahmondang.
sentence2: "I will improve on that dull fellow," said Ko-ko.

sentence1: "I will improve on that dull fellow," said Ko-ko.
sentence2: "I will put them on myself."

sentence1: "I will put them on myself."
sentence2: Accordingly, Ko-ko had just time to draw on the moccasins when the wicked father came in sight.

sentence1: Accordingly, Ko-ko had just time to draw on the moccasins when the wicked father came in sight.
sentence2: but to the astonishment of the Owl, they turned immediately about in the way in which the wicked father, now, very furious, was approaching.

sentence1: but to the astonishment of the Owl, they turned immediately about in the way in which the wicked father, now, very furious, was approaching.
sentence2: and before he could shake himself out of them, they had run him directly into the face of the wicked father.

sentence1: and before he could shake himself out of them, they had run him directly into the face of the wicked father.
sentence2: "What do you mean, you Owl?"

sentence1: "What do you mean, you Owl?"
sentence2: cried the wicked father, falling upon Ko-ko with a huge club, and counting his ribs at every stroke.

sentence1: cried the wicked father, falling upon Ko-ko with a huge club, and counting his ribs at every stroke.
sentence2: "I can not help it, good man," answered Ko-ko.

sentence1: "I can not help it, good man," answered Ko-ko.
sentence2: "I tried my best-" Ko-ko would have gone the other way, but the enchanted moccasins kept hurrying him forward.

sentence1: "I tried my best-" Ko-ko would have gone the other way, but the enchanted moccasins kept hurrying him forward.
sentence2: cried the old man.

sentence1: cried the old man.
sentence2: By this time, allowing the wicked father chance to bestow no more than five-and-twenty more blows upon Ko-ko, the moccasins were taking him past.

sentence1: By this time, allowing the wicked father chance to bestow no more than five-and-twenty more blows upon Ko-ko, the moccasins were taking him past.
sentence2: cried the old man again.

sentence1: cried the old man again.
sentence2: "I am not, good man," answered Ko-ko, carried away by the magical shoes, "I assure you."

sentence1: "I am not, good man," answered Ko-ko, carried away by the magical shoes, "I assure you."
sentence2: But ere he could finish his avowal, the moccasins had hurried him out of sight.

sentence1: But ere he could finish his avowal, the moccasins had hurried him out of sight.
sentence2: "At any rate, I shall soon be home at this speed," said Ko-koor to himself.

sentence1: "At any rate, I shall soon be home at this speed," said Ko-koor to himself.
sentence2: The moccasins seemed to know his thoughts;

sentence1: The moccasins seemed to know his thoughts;
sentence2: for just then they gave a sudden leap, slipped away from his feet, and left the Owl flat upon his back!

sentence1: for just then they gave a sudden leap, slipped away from his feet, and left the Owl flat upon his back!
sentence2: while they glided home by themselves, to the lodge of Onwee Bahmondang, where they belonged.

sentence1: while they glided home by themselves, to the lodge of Onwee Bahmondang, where they belonged.
sentence2: A party of hunters passing that way after several days, found Ko-ko sitting among the bushes, looking greatly bewildered;

sentence1: A party of hunters passing that way after several days, found Ko-ko sitting among the bushes, looking greatly bewildered;
sentence2: and when they inquired of him how he had succeeded with the wicked father at the lodge, he answered that he had demolished the whole establishment, but that his name was not Ko-ko, but Onwee Bahmondang;

sentence1: and when they inquired of him how he had succeeded with the wicked father at the lodge, he answered that he had demolished the whole establishment, but that his name was not Ko-ko, but Onwee Bahmondang;
sentence2: saying which, he ran away into the woods, and was never seen more.
